titleStmt.title: IL-1 receptor activation undermines respiratory motor plasticity after systemic inflammation

analytic.title: IL-1 receptor activation undermines respiratory motor plasticity after systemic inflammation

biblStruct.note: Submitted 29 November 2017; accepted in final form 19 March 2018

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Inflammation undermines respiratory motor plasticity, yet we are just beginning to understand the inflammatory signaling involved.

Because interleukin-1 (IL-1) signaling promotes or inhibits plasticity in other central nervous system regions, we tested the following hypotheses: 1) IL-1 receptor (IL-1R) activation after systemic inflammation is necessary to undermine phrenic long-term facilitation (pLTF), a model of respiratory motor plasticity induced by acute intermittent hypoxia (AIH), and 2) spinal IL-1␤ is sufficient to undermine pLTF.

pLTF is significantly reduced 24 h after lipopolysaccharide (LPS; 100 g/kg ip, 12 Ϯ 18%, n ϭ 5) compared with control (57 Ϯ 25%, n ϭ 6) and restored by peripheral IL-1R antagonism (63 Ϯ 13%, n ϭ 5, AF-12198, 0.5 mg/kg ip, 24 h).

Furthermore, acute, spinal IL-1R antagonism (1 mM AF-12198, 15 l it) restored pLTF (53 Ϯ 15%, n ϭ 4) compared with LPS-treated rats (11 Ϯ 10%; n ϭ 5), demonstrating IL-1R activation is necessary to undermine pLTF after systemic inflammation.

However, in healthy animals, pLTF persisted after spinal, exogenous recombinant rat IL-1␤ (rIL-1␤) (1 ng Ϯ AIH; 66 Ϯ 26%, n ϭ 3, 10 ng Ϯ AIH; 102 Ϯ 49%, n ϭ 4, 100 ng ϩ AIH; 93 Ϯ 51%, n ϭ 3, 300 ng Ϯ AIH; 37 Ϯ 40%, n ϭ 3; P Ͻ 0.05 from baseline).

In the absence of AIH, spinal rIL-1␤ induced progressive, dose-dependent phrenic amplitude facilitation (1 ng; Ϫ3 Ϯ 5%, n ϭ 3, 10 ng; 8 Ϯ 22%, n ϭ 3, 100 ng; 31 Ϯ 12%, P Ͻ 0.05, n ϭ 4, 300 ng; 51 Ϯ 17%, P Ͻ 0.01 from baseline, n ϭ 4).
In sum, IL-1R activation, both systemically and spinally, undermines pLTF after LPSinduced systemic inflammation, but IL-1R activation is not sufficient to abolish plasticity.

Understanding the inflammatory signaling inhibiting respiratory plasticity is crucial to developing treatment strategies utilizing respiratory plasticity to promote breathing during ventilatory control disorders.
NEW & NOTEWORTHY This study gives novel insights concerning mechanisms by which systemic inflammation undermines respiratory motor plasticity.
We demonstrate that interleukin-1 signaling, both peripherally and centrally, undermines respiratory motor plasticity.
However, acute, exogenous interleukin-1 signaling is not sufficient to undermine respiratory motor plasticity.

Our understanding of how systemic inflammation alters central nervous system (CNS) function has accelerated with the identification of peripheral cytokines inducing CNS inflamma-tion by crossing the blood-brain barrier, entering the CNS at circumventricular organs, activating vagal afferents (22,29), or activating blood-brain barrier endothelial cells and glia (9,26,37).
In turn, this peripheral to central inflammatory signaling alters CNS function by modulating glia (30) and significantly affecting neuroplasticity (16).
A complicated relationship exists between inflammatory signaling and neuroplasticity.
Inflammatory signaling in the CNS promotes and inhibits distinct forms of neuroplasticity in different CNS regions through the actions of the interleukin-1 (IL-1) signaling cascade.
CNS IL-1␤ and its corresponding IL-1 receptor (IL-1R) are upregulated after systemic inflammation induced experimentally by lipopolysaccharide (LPS) (16,25,48).
IL-1␤ is sufficient to inhibit hippocampal-dependent memory formation and long-term potentiation, a form of plasticity important for learning and memory formation (27).

However, a genetic knockout of the IL-1R undermines hippocampal-dependent memory formation and abolishes plasticity in the form of long-term potentiation (2,15,41), demonstrating IL-1 signaling both contributes to and undermines hippocampal plasticity.
Conversely, spinal pain hypersensitivity, a form of neuroplasticity in the spinal dorsal horn, is induced by inflammatory stimuli involving IL-1R activation (10,31,49).
Thus, IL-1␤ and IL-1Rs have complicated effects on neuroplasticity, whereby IL-1R signaling can either promote or inhibit plasticity depending on the CNS region in which this plasticity is occurring.
The respiratory control system, like other CNS regions, undergoes plasticity to confer stability and adaptability to respiratory output (13,34).
Phrenic long-term facilitation (pLTF) is a frequently studied model of neuroplasticity in the respiratory control system (34).

pLTF is induced by acute intermittent hypoxia (AIH: three 5-min hypoxic episodes, separated by 5-min normoxic periods) and manifests as a progressive increase in phrenic nerve burst amplitude following AIH.
Previously, we have shown pLTF is abolished by systemic inflammation and IL-1␤ gene expression increases after systemic inflammation in the cervical spinal cord (24,25).
However, the inflammatory signaling cascades involved in undermining plasticity in the respiratory system are not fully understood.

Given the central role for IL-1R signaling in other forms of plasticity and increased IL-1␤ gene expression in the cervical spinal cord [purportedly where pLTF occurs (3)] after systemic inflammation, we investigated the necessity and sufficiency of IL-1 signaling in undermining pLTF after systemic inflammation.
We demonstrate that IL-1R activation, both systemically and centrally, undermines pLTF after LPS-induced systemic inflammation.
Yet, in healthy rats, acute, exogenous IL-1␤ spinally was not sufficient to undermine pLTF.
Overall, our findings further our mechanistic understanding of how plasticity in the neural control of breathing is abolished by systemic inflammation.

All experiments were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee at the University of Oregon and conformed to the policies of the National Institutes of Health Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals.
Male Sprague Dawley rats (300 -400 g; 3-4 mo; colonies 217 and 206, Envigo, Huntingdon, UK) were housed under standard conditions with a 12:12 h light/dark cycle with food and water ad libitum.
Drugs and materials.
LPS (0111:B4, SigmaChemical) was dissolved and sonicated in sterile saline to a working concentration of 100 g/ml given via intraperitoneal injections.

The IL-1R antagonist AF-12198 (Toronto Research Chemicals, North York, Canada) was dissolved in 10% ethanol and sterile saline for peripheral injections (0.5 mg/ml) or in fresh artificial cerebrospinal fluid (aCSF; 120 mM NaCl, 3 mM KCl, 2 mM CaCl 2, 2 mM MgCl2, 23 mM NaHCO3, and 10 mM glucose) for intrathecal injections (1 mM).
Recombinant rat IL-1␤ (rIL-1␤, 4130, BioVision, Milpitas, CA) was dissolved in aCSF for intrathecal injections (0.25-10 ng/l).
Experimental groups.

To investigate the necessity of peripheral IL-1R activation in undermining pLTF, we used the following experimental groups: 1) LPS (100 g/kg ip, 24 h before AIH) ϩ AF-12198 (0.5 mg/kg ip, 24 h before AIH), n ϭ 5; 2) LPS ϩ vehicle (10% ethanol in sterile saline), n ϭ 5; 3) saline (LPS vehicle ip) ϩ AF-12198, n ϭ 6; 4) saline ϩ vehicle, n ϭ 5; 5) time control (TC), which consists of rats from each of the previous treatment groups (LPS ϩ AF-12198 ip, n ϭ 4; saline ϩ AF-12198 ip, n ϭ 5; LPS ϩ vehicle ip, n ϭ 4; saline ϩ vehicle ip, n ϭ 4).

To investigate the necessity of spinal IL-1R activation in undermining pLTF after systemic inflammation, we used the following experimental groups: 1) LPS (100 g/kg ip, 24 h before AIH) ϩ AF-12198 (1 mM, 15 l it, 20 min before AIH), n ϭ 4; 2) LPS ϩ vehicle (10% ethanol in sterile saline it), n ϭ 5; 3) saline ip ϩ AF-12198 it, n ϭ 4; 4) saline ϩ vehicle it, n ϭ 4; 5) TCs, which consist of rats from each of the previous treatment groups (LPS ϩ AF-12198 it, n ϭ 4; saline ϩ AF-12198 it, n ϭ 3; LPS ϩ vehicle it, n ϭ 4; saline ϩ vehicle it, n ϭ 4).
To investigate the sufficiency of acute, exogenous, spinal rIL-1␤ to undermine pLTF, we performed a dose-response with exogenous rIL-1␤ (it) at 1, 10, 100, and 300 ng.
AIH was performed 20 min after spinal rIL-1␤ injections.

To investigate the effects of acute, exogenous, spinal rIL-1␤ on phrenic burst facilitation in the absence of AIH, rIL-1␤ (1, 10, 100, and 300 ng it) was applied over the cervical spinal cord and phrenic neural output monitored over the next 105 min.
Electrophysiological studies.
Electrophysiological studies have been described in detail previously (24).
Rats were anesthetized with isoflurane, tracheotomized, ventilated (Rat Ventilator, VetEquip, Livermore, CA), and bilaterally vagotomized.
A venous catheter was placed for drug delivery and fluid replacement, and a femoral arterial catheter was used for arterial blood analysis and monitoring blood pressure.

Arterial blood samples were analyzed [arterial pressure of oxygen (Pa O 2 ), arterial pressure of carbon dioxide (Pa CO 2 ), pH, and base excess; RAPIDLAB 248, Siemens] before AIH, during the first hypoxic response, and 15, 30, and 60 min post-AIH.
Temperature was measured with a rectal temperature probe (Kent Scientific) and maintained between 37°C and 38°C with a heated table.
Using a dorsal approach, hypoglossal and phrenic nerves were dissected, cut distally, and desheathed.
Rats were converted to urethane anesthesia (1.8 g/kg iv; Sigma-Aldrich), allowed to stabilize over the next hour, and paralyzed with pancuronium dibromide (1 mg/rat; Selleck Chemicals).
In rats receiving intrathecal injections, a laminectomy was performed at cervical vertebrae 2, and a primed, silicone catheter was inserted 2 mm through a small incision in the dura.
The catheter tip extended toward the rostral margin of cervical vertebrae 4 (4).
AF-12198 (1 mM) or vehicle (aCSF) was injected (15 l) 20 min before AIH.

rIL-1␤ was applied intrathecally 20 min before the start of AIH at doses of 1 ng (4 l of 0.2 ng/l), 10 ng (10 l of 1 ng/l), 100 ng (10 l of 10 ng/l), and 300 ng (30 l of 10 ng/l in 10 l boluses over 3 min).
In rats receiving rIL-1␤ intrathecally but not AIH, all time points were matched with rIL-1␤ ϩ AIH experiments.
Nerves were bathed in mineral oil and placed on bipolar silver wire electrodes.

Raw nerve recordings were amplified (10 k), filtered (0.1-5 kHz), integrated (50-ms time constant), and recorded (10-kHz sampling rate) for offline analysis (PowerLab and LabChart 8.0, AD Instruments).
Apneic and recruitment CO 2 thresholds were determined by changing inspired CO2 with continuous end-tidal CO2 monitoring (Kent Scientific Corporation).

End-tidal CO2 was set 2 mmHg above the recruitment threshold, and arterial blood samples were used to establish baseline Pa CO 2 , which was maintained within 1.5 mmHg of the baseline value throughout.
Blood volume and base excess were maintained (Ϯ3 MEq/l) by continuous infusion (1-3 ml/h iv) of hetastarch (0.3%) and sodium bicarbonate (0.99%) in lactated ringers.
Experiments were excluded if mean arterial pressure (MAP) deviated more than 20 mmHg from baseline versus 60 min after AIH.
All rats (except for TC rats) received three 5-min bouts of hypoxia (~10.5% O 2, Pa O 2 35-45 mmHg) separated by 5 min of normoxia.

The average amplitude and frequency of 30 consecutive integrated phrenic bursts were analyzed at baseline, during the first acute hypoxic response, and 15, 30, and 60 min after AIH and made relative to baseline amplitude.
Physiological variables and phrenic nerve activity data for each experimental group were compared using two-way, repeated-measures ANOVA with Fisher least-significant difference (LSD) post hoc tests.
TC data were grouped for each experimental design because no significant differences between experimental groups were found (repeated-measures ANOVA, Fisher LSD post hoc).
MAP is reported from baseline, the end of the final hypoxic exposure, and 60 min after AIH.
Acute hypoxic responses were compared using an ANOVA with Fisher LSD post hoc test.
Values are means Ϯ SD.
Peripheral IL-1R activation is necessary for undermining pLTF after peripheral LPS.
Saline ϩ AF-12198 vehicle (ip) and saline ϩ AF-12198 (ip) rats exhibited pLTF 60 min after AIH (57 Ϯ 25%, P Ͻ 0.0001, n ϭ 6; 44 Ϯ 14%, P Ͻ 0.0001, n ϭ 5, respectively; Fig. 1).
As expected (25), pLTF was eliminated in LPS ϩ vehicle (ip) rats (12 Ϯ 18%, P Ͻ 0.05, n ϭ 6; Fig. 1).
pLTF was restored by peripheral antagonism of IL-1Rs [LPS Ϯ AF-12198 (ip), 63 Ϯ 13%, P Ͻ 0.0001, n ϭ 5; Fig. 1] and was not evident in any TC groups (Ϫ1 Ϯ 9% P ϭ 0.24, n ϭ 17).
No significant differences in the magnitude of pLTF were evident between LPS ϩ AF-12198 (ip) and saline ϩ AF-12198 (ip) groups.

The acute hypoxic phrenic response was unaffected by LPS or IL-1R antagonism [saline ϩ vehicle (ip), 133 Ϯ 39%; LPS ϩ vehicle (ip), 129 Ϯ 49%; saline ϩ AF-12198 (ip), 104 Ϯ 46%; LPS ϩ AF-12198 (ip), 129 Ϯ 30%; Fig. 1C]; no significant differences were present between groups.

LPS caused a small, but significant, increase in baseline phrenic burst frequency compared with saline controls [LPS ϩ vehicle (ip), 51 Ϯ 6 bursts/min; saline ϩ vehicle (ip), 43 Ϯ 8 bursts/min; P ϭ 0.021].
However, AF-12198 had no effect on baseline burst frequency between groups [LPS Ϯ AF-12198 (ip), 49 Ϯ 5 bursts/min; saline ϩ AF-12198 (ip), 45 Ϯ 5 bursts/min].
Frequency long-term facilitation was not evident 60 min post-AIH in any experimental group.
Small variations were evident in physiological parameters (Table 1) but remained within experimental limits.
As expected, all experimental groups displayed significantly decreased MAP and Pa O 2 during hypoxia.
Temperature 60 min after AIH was significantly different in saline ϩ vehicle and LPS ϩ AF-12198 (ip) groups relative to baseline but remained within experimental limits noted above.
Similarly, 60 min after AIH small differences were evident between groups in Pa O 2 and pH but remained within acceptable limits (Table 1).
Spinal IL-1R activation is necessary for undermining pLTF after peripheral LPS.
We next tested the hypothesis that acute, spinal IL-1R activation is necessary to undermine pLTF 24 h after peripheral LPS (Fig. 2).
Saline ϩ vehicle (it) rats exhibited pLTF 60 min after AIH (60 Ϯ 18%, P Ͻ 0.0001, n ϭ 4).

AF-12198 (it) did not significantly increase the magnitude of pLTF in saline-treated rats Small variations were evident in physiological parameters (Table 2), but they remained within experimental limits.
As expected, all experimental groups displayed significantly decreased MAP and Pa O 2 during hypoxia.
There were no significant differences in temperature, Pa CO 2 , or pH at baseline.
The significant decrease in Pa O 2 at 60 min in the saline ϩ vehicle (it) group was within normal limits.
At baseline, LPS treatment increased MAP relative to saline-treated groups with AF-12198 or vehicle (Table 2).
Spinal exogenous rIL-1␤ does not abolish AIH-induced pLTF in healthy rats.

pLTF remains after spinal, exogenous rIL-1␤ (1 ng Ϯ AIH; 66 Ϯ 26%, n ϭ 3, P ϭ 0.012, 10 ng Ϯ AIH; 102 Ϯ 49%, n ϭ 4, P Ͻ 0.0001, 100 ng ϩ AIH; 93 Ϯ 51%, n ϭ 3, P Ͻ 0.0001, 300 ng Ϯ AIH; 37 Ϯ 40%, n ϭ 3, P ϭ 0.028).
However, after 300 ng rIL-1␤, AIH elicited pLTF with lower magnitude than 10-ng (P ϭ 0.008) and 100-ng doses (P ϭ 0.014, Fig. 3A).
Therefore, rIL-1␤ is not sufficient to abolish pLTF in healthy rats.
Furthermore, rIL-1␤ had no effect on the acute hypoxic phrenic responses at any dose (1 ng, 154 Ϯ 63%; 10 ng, 220 Ϯ 131%; 100 ng, 143 Ϯ 55%; 300 ng, 96 Ϯ 52%).
Minor changes in physiological variables occurred in animals receiving intrathecal rIL-1␤ and AIH (Table 3).
Temperature was decreased at 60 min in the 1 ng ϩ AIH group but remained within acceptable ranges.
There were no significant differences in Pa CO 2 and small, but significant, changes in pH during hypoxia in 1 ng ϩ AIH and 300 ng ϩ AIH groups.
Pa O 2 and MAP were significantly decreased during hypoxia (Table 3).
Spinal exogenous rIL-1␤ facilitates phrenic amplitude in healthy rats.

Since exogenous IL-1␤ is sufficient to induce plasticity in the spinal dorsal horn in the form of pain hypersensitivity [Cunha et al. ( 10)], we next tested the hypothesis that spinal rIL-1␤ was sufficient to facilitate phrenic nerve amplitude.

Low doses of rIL-1␤ (1 ng and 10 ng) did not significantly alter phrenic amplitude (1 ng; Ϫ3 Ϯ 5%, n ϭ 3, P ϭ 0.738, 10 ng; 8 Ϯ 22%, n ϭ 3, P ϭ 0.380); however, higher doses of rIL-1␤ induced progressive phrenic amplitude facilitation (100 ng; 31 Ϯ 12%, P ϭ 0.005 relative to baseline, n ϭ 4, 300 ng; 51 Ϯ 17%, P Ͻ 0 0.0001 relative to baseline, n ϭ 4).
Therefore, high doses of rIL-1␤ are sufficient to facilitate phrenic amplitude (Fig. 4).
Physiological variables were stable throughout electrophysiology experiments without any significant changes (Table 3).
Here, we demonstrate a role for IL-1R activation, both peripherally and centrally, in systemic inflammation-induced impairment of respiratory motor plasticity.
In healthy rats, however, activation of IL-1Rs with exogenous rIL-1␤ is insufficient to abolish AIH-induced pLTF yet induces phrenic amplitude facilitation in the absence of AIH.
Therefore, IL-1R activation is necessary to abolish pLTF after systemic inflammation but not sufficient to abolish pLTF in healthy rats.
These data demonstrate IL-1R activation is an important signaling step in abolishing respiratory plasticity after systemic inflammation.

CNS responses to IL-1␤ have been widely studied because IL-1␤ plays a role in modulating many physiological systems, including thermoregulation and behavioral responses (32,50), and IL-1␤ is rapidly upregulated in the CNS after LPS-induced systemic inflammation (40).

More recently, IL-1 signaling in the CNS has been shown to modulate different forms of neuroplasticity, including hippocampal-dependent learning and pain sensitivity in the dorsal spinal cord (10,31,49).
We now demonstrate a role for IL-1R activation in undermining respiratory plasticity in the cervical spinal cord.
The restoration of pLTF by peripheral IL-1R antagonism suggests IL-1R activation is necessary for transmitting relevant inflammatory information to the CNS after LPS-induced inflammation.
Additionally, because IL-1R signaling likely contributes significantly to time-dependent changes in serum cytokine levels ( 44 after peripheral LPS (25).
Thus, we suggest the primary action of peripheral IL-1R antagonism is to inhibit peripheral inflammatory responses induced by LPS.
It remains possible, however, that AF-12198 crosses the blood-brain barrier and also directly reduces CNS inflammatory responses.
Because AF-12198 is a small peptide, we believe it is unlikely to cross the blood-brain barrier at sufficient concentrations to reduce CNS inflammation directly.
Thus, the actions of peripheral IL-1R antagonism are most likely by inhibiting peripheral inflammatory responses.
Together, we propose peripheral IL-1R antagonism indirectly reduces relevant spinal inflammation and, therefore, restores pLTF.

Our data demonstrating restoration of pLTF by spinal IL-1R antagonism are consistent with the hypothesis that persistent IL-1 signaling around the phrenic motor pool is necessary for undermining pLTF (11,12).

IL-1R signaling in phrenic motoneurons could directly alter their properties to eliminate pLTF or could promote the release of other inflammatory cytokines from nearby cells (such as microglia) that undermine pLTF.
IL-1R signaling can activate diverse intracellular proinflammatory pathways including NF-B and stress-activated protein kinases (16a), which may inhibit pLTF.
Additionally, in a separate model of systemic inflammation, spinal p38-MAPK activation, a kinase downstream of IL-1R (35), is necessary to undermine pLTF after systemic inflammation (24).
Future investigations should assess the link between spinal IL-1 signaling and activation of p38-MAPK in undermining pLTF.
Although we demonstrate the necessity of IL-1R activation in undermining plasticity, the effects of direct application of rIL-1␤ are more complicated.
Here, no rIL-1␤ dose abolished plasticity after AIH in healthy rats.
The 300-ng rIL-1␤ dose did reduce the magnitude of pLTF compared with other doses.

Therefore, it is possible higher doses of rIL-1␤ may be sufficient to undermine pLTF; however, 300 ng is the highest dose possible because of solubility and volume limitations for intrathecal injections.

Exogenous rIL-1␤ may be insufficient to undermine pLTF if complementary inflammatory molecules are necessary to undermine pLTF completely or if systemic inflammation primes the CNS to augment the response to IL-1␤.
For example, IL-1R expression is upregulated after peripheral LPS (48) such that healthy animals not exposed to LPS have a blunted response to exogenous rIL-1␤.
Alternatively, the cellular mechanisms undermining pLTF may take longer to develop than 20 min after spinal, exogenous rIL-1␤.
However, in hippocampal slices, rIL-1␤ inhibits long-term potentiation within 10 min of exposure ( 6), demonstrating rIL-1␤ can have rapid effects.

In the absence of AIH, high doses of rIL-1␤ facilitated phrenic burst amplitude, demonstrating rIL-1␤ evoked a lasting increase in phrenic amplitude after lasting increase in phenic amplitude, even after IL-1␤ is likely degraded (38).

Although the mechanisms mediating this plasticity are unknown, other reports show dose-dependent IL-1␤ changes in synaptic strength or cell excitability in response to IL-1R activation, such as increased calcium-dependent glutamate release from hippocampal neurons, upregulated N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor activity (18), and increased dorsal root ganglion neuron excitability after IL-1␤ (7,43).
Taken together, rIL-1␤ exerts dose-dependent alterations of phrenic motor output capable of both inducing facilitation and reducing the magnitude of, but not abolishing, pLTF.

Although our study demonstrates an important role of IL-1 signaling in spinal motor respiratory plasticity, IL-1 signaling is likely not the only inflammatory molecule involved in modulating respiratory neural activity.
For example, inactivityinduced phrenic motor facilitation, another model of spinal respiratory motor plasticity, requires the activation of TNF receptor 1, an inflammatory cytokine receptor (8).
Additional inflammatory molecules, such as prostaglandins, have also been shown to modulate central respiratory networks.

Although prostaglandins mediate profound respiratory modulation (17,28,36,42), they are unlikely to play a significant role in undermining respiratory motor plasticity after systemic inflammation because inhibition of cyclooxygenase, the ratelimiting enzyme in the production of prostaglandins, does not restore pLTF (23).
However, the relationship between the various types of inflammatory cytokines and their downstream effects in respiratory control remains mostly unknown.

Improving our understanding of the actions of individual and combined inflammatory signaling molecules, as well as their cellular sources, in neural respiratory control will be the topic of future investigations.
Our study builds on these and other recent studies investigating the effects of IL-1 signaling in respiratory control networks (1,39).
Similar to previous reports (1, 20), we found a tendency for systemic inflammation to increase baseline phrenic burst frequency.

Although the mechanisms mediating the increased frequency after systemic inflammation are unclear, direct intracerebroventricular rIL-1␤ increases minute ventilation, suggesting a direct effect of IL-1␤ on respiratory frequency (1).

Additionally, acute hypoxic ventilatory responses are attenuated after intratracheal LPS because of spinal IL-1R activation (39); however, no significant changes were seen in the acute hypoxic phrenic amplitude response after systemic inflammation.
Furthermore, frequency LTF was only evident in one experimental group, which supports previous work suggesting frequency LTF is small and inconsistent (5).
Less is known about the mechanisms underlying frequency LTF, which may be distinctly different from the amplitude change known as pLTF.

Thus, we have focused our analyses on amplitude changes because much more is known about the mechanism of pLTF using this experimental preparation and the AIH paradigm, where the consistent and significant changes are reflected in amplitude.
In sum, IL-1 signaling seems to have widespread roles in the neural control of breathing.
In conclusion, we demonstrate IL-1R activation, peripherally and centrally, is necessary for undermining respiratory plasticity after systemic inflammation.

Our study is the first to our knowledge to investigate the effects of IL-1 signaling on spinal respiratory plasticity and builds on other recent studies investigating the effects of IL-1 signaling in medullary respiratory networks (1,39).
Taken together, inflammatory signaling through IL-1R attenuates chemosensitivity (1) and respiratory plasticity.
Furthermore, such results suggest uncovering how inflammation impacts the neural control of breathing is fundamental to understand changes in respiratory function during pathological conditions.
Furthermore, for respiratory motor plasticity to be used clinically (21,45,46), we must also understand the interaction between plasticity and inflammation, which is common in many pathologies.
This work was supported by the Francis Family Foundation (to A. Huxtable ).
Fig. 1.
Peripheral interleukin-1 receptor (IL-1R) antagonism restores phrenic long-term facilitation (pLTF) after systemic inflammation.

Representative integrated phrenic neurograms (A) for acute intermittent hypoxia (AIH)-treated rats receiving saline ϩ vehicle (ip), lipopolysaccharide (LPS; 100 g/kg ip) ϩ vehicle (ip), saline ϩ AF-12198 (ip), LPS ϩ AF-12198 (ip), and a time control (no AIH).
pLTF is evident as the progressive increase in phrenic nerve amplitude from baseline (dashed line) over 60 min following AIH.
Group data (B) demonstrate pLTF is abolished by LPS (vehicle-treated, dark grey bars) and restored by peripheral IL-1R antagonism (AF-12198-treated, light grey bars).
Acute hypoxic responses (C) were not significantly altered by any treatment (ANOVA).

***P Ͻ 0.0001 significant difference in phrenic amplitude from baseline; #different from Saline ϩ Vehicle (P Ͻ 0.001), Saline ϩ AF-12198 (P Ͻ 0.05), and LPS ϩ AF-12198 (P Ͻ 0.001); ##P Ͻ 0.001 different from Saline ϩ Vehicle, Saline ϩ AF-12198, and LPS ϩ AF-12198 (repeated-measures ANOVA, Fisher least-significant difference).
Hx, hypoxia; Phr, phrenic.
Fig. 2. Spinal interleukin-1 receptor (IL-1R) antagonism restores phrenic long-term facilitation (pLTF) after systemic inflammation.

Representative integrated phrenic neurograms (A) for acute intermittent hypoxia (AIH)-treated rats receiving saline ϩ vehicle it lipopolysaccharide (LPS; 100 g/kg ip) ϩ vehicle (it), Saline ϩ AF-12198 (1 mM, 15 l, it), LPS (ip) ϩ AF-12198 (it), and a time control (no AIH).
pLTF is evident as the progressive increase in phrenic nerve amplitude from baseline (dashed line) over 60 min following AIH.
Group data (B) demonstrate pLTF is abolished by LPS ϩ vehicle (dark gray bars) and restored by intrathecal IL-1R antagonism (AF-12198 treated, light grey bars).
Acute hypoxic responses (C) were not significantly affected by any treatment.

***P Ͻ 0.0001 significant difference in phrenic amplitude from baseline; #P Ͻ 0.001 different from saline ϩ vehicle, saline ϩ AF-12198, and LPS ϩ AF-12198 (repeated-measures ANOVA, Fisher least-significant difference).
Hx, hypoxia; Phr, phrenic.
Fig. Exogenous, spinal recombinant rat interleukin 1␤ (rIL-1␤) does not abolish phrenic long-term facilitation (pLTF) in healthy animals.
Representative integrated phrenic neurograms (A) after intrathecal rIL-1␤ (1, 10, 100, and 300 ng; indicated by 2) 20 min before acute intermittent hypoxia (AIH).
pLTF is evident as the progressive increase in phrenic nerve amplitude from baseline (dashed line) over 60 min following AIH.
Intrathecal rIL-1␤ does not abolish pLTF at any dose.
Group data (B) demonstrate pLTF at all doses of intrathecal rIL-1␤, but the magnitude of pLTF at high doses (300 ng) is reduced compared with lower doses (10 and 100 ng).
Acute hypoxic phrenic responses (C) were not significantly affected by any treatment.

*P Ͻ 0.05; **P Ͻ 0.01; ***P Ͻ 0.001 significantly different from baseline; a P Ͻ 0.05 significantly different from 10 ng ϩ AIH and 100 ng ϩ AIH (repeated-measures ANOVA, Fisher least-significant difference).
Hx, hypoxia; Phr, phrenic.
Fig. 4. Exogenous, spinal rat interleukin 1␤ (rIL-1␤) induces dose-dependent facilitation of phrenic amplitude.
Representative integrated phrenic neurograms (A) for rats receiving intrathecal rIL-1␤ (1, 10, 100, and 300 ng, indicated by 2).
Phrenic amplitude facilitation is evident as the progressive increase in phrenic nerve amplitude from baseline (dashed line) following intrathecal rIL-1␤.
Group data (B) demonstrate a dose-dependent increase in phrenic nerve amplitude 60 min after intrathecal rIL-1␤.

**P Ͻ 0.01; ***P Ͻ 0.001 significantly different from baseline; a P Ͻ 0.05 significantly different from 1 ng ϩ TC; b P Ͻ 0.01 significantly different from 1 ng ϩ TC and 10 ng ϩ TC (repeated-measures ANOVA, Fisher leastsignificant difference).
TC, time control; Phr, phrenic.
Physiological Pa CO 2 , arterial pressure of carbon dioxide; Pa O 2 , arterial pressure of oxygen; MAP, mean arterial pressure; TC, time control.
a P Ͻ 0.05 different from baseline within group.
baseline, n ϭ 4].
pLTF was not apparent in the TC group (6 Ϯ 17%, P ϭ 0.241, n ϭ 15).

The acute hypoxic phrenic response was not significantly affected by LPS or spinal IL-1R antagonism [saline ϩ vehicle (it), 117 Ϯ 23%; LPS ϩ vehicle (it), 169 Ϯ 45%; saline ϩ AF-12198 (it), 150 Ϯ 61%; LPS Ϯ AF-12198 (it), 104 Ϯ 36%].

Baseline phrenic burst frequency was not significantly different between any groups [saline ϩ vehicle (it), 45 Ϯ 6 bursts/min; saline ϩ AF-12198 (it), 45 Ϯ 3 bursts/min; LPS ϩ vehicle (it), 44 Ϯ 4 bursts/min; LPS Ϯ AF-12198 (it), 47 Ϯ 10 bursts/min, P ϭ 0.9528].
Frequency LTF was evident in saline ϩ AF-12198 (it) rats 60 min after AIH (4 Ϯ 2 bursts/ min, P ϭ 0.0138) but not in any other group.
